entry.title: Multiple entries in VEKP for the same EXIDV in EWM decentralized scenario
entry.content:
We create and manage Handling Units (HUs) in our production plant , which is HU managed. We then transfer these HUs to the distribution center, which is EWM (decentralized) managed, using a Stock Transport Order (STO). Subsequently, we send the HU back to the production plant for any reason.

Upon checking the VEKP, we notice that this process results in three records for the same EXIDV, which  creates issues for us.

Could you please let me know if this is a standard behavior and if someone has experiences the same behavior?

 

Thanks

 

Claudio

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud for adv. variant config - professional
entry.content:
Hello @SKAE 

Below clarifies the significance or implication.

  • Measured = 4 → Four users in your S/4HANA Cloud tenant have business roles or catalogues that require the S/4HANA Cloud for advanced variant configuration – professional licence.
  • Subscribed = 0 → Your contract does not include entitlements for that SKU, so the system indicates possible over-consumption.
    Measurement in the Public Cloud is role-based, not user-based, and is determined by the catalogue.

Here's a simple way to identify the 4 users with just two quick checks

IAM Information System app

    • Add the Required Licence column.
    • Filter for the AVC Professional licence.
    • Drill into the roles/catalogues to see the users assigned.

SAP for Me → Consumption → Cloud Licence Consumption

    • Open your S/4HANA product.
    • Download the user details file to cross-verify the same four users.

Common trigger
For roles involving Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC) modelling applications, such as engineering, research and development, or related content, the AVC – Professional licence is required. This ensures you have the right tools and access to excel in these areas.

Resolution options

  • If these users don’t need AVC modelling: remove or swap the AVC-professional catalogues from their roles.
  • If necessary, buy entitlements for the appropriate number of users.

If you share a screenshot of your IAM filter result, I can identify the specific catalogue(s) responsible for the measurement.

Below are some useful SAP documentation

IAM Information System-SAP Help

Cloud License Consumption reporting in SAP for Me Customer Insights -SAP Community

SAP S/4HANA Cloud for advanced variant configuration

Licence Compliance-SAP Help

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Automating S/4HANA Cloud UI Deployment via CI/CD Pipe...
entry.content:
Hi @niklas-weissenfels 

You are right, the deploy-to-abap task in your ui5-deploy.yaml currently uses re-entrance ticket authentication, which works fine for interactive deployments but not for automated CI/CD pipelines. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you cannot use a re-entrance ticket with a technical user. Instead, you need to switch to service key / OAuth2 token-based authentication using a Communication User and Communication Arrangement.

 

Here are Authentication in Automated Deployments

  • For CI/CD, SAP does not recommend re-entrance tickets.
  • The supported option is to configure OAuth 2.0 with S/4HANA Cloud via a Communication Arrangement.
  • You create a Communication User which is the technical user and generate credentials such as client ID, client secret and token URL.

Here is a communication scenario you can use

  • For deploying UI5/Fiori applications into S/4HANA Public Cloud, you should use Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0466 (Software Lifecycle Management  Extensibility).
  • This allows deployment of extensions into the ABAP system with a service key, not a re-entrance ticket.

Here are CI/CD Configuration Steps to consider

  1. In S/4HANA Cloud:
    • Create a Communication User.
    • Create a Communication System.
    • Create a Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0466 and assign your user.
    • This gives you the OAuth token service URL, client ID and secret.
  2. In your CI/CD pipeline:
    • Use these credentials to request an OAuth token from the S/4HANA Cloud token endpoint.
    • Configure ui5-deploy.yaml with authentication Type: oauth2 instead of re-entrance Ticket.
  3. Run Fiori deploy in the pipeline with the OAuth token.

These references provide more details

Deploying UI5 Applications with deploy-to-abap

Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0466

SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:
Hello @MKreitlein , 

The change of login to SAP´s digital platforms is mainly necessary from a technical viewpoint. It simplifies the authentication in general as it streamlines with SAP´s  authentication mechanism (SAP IAS). And it is paving the way to further developments as you can read in our News Article, that is also linked above. The transition should be regarded from this broader perspective. 

To get a better understanding where we are going with the authentication to digital platforms, also this interview on YouTube might be interesting for you. 

Nevertheless, the SAP Universal ID remains active: Users can link their user identities (S-/P-users), they can have their SAP Universal ID linked to a personal email address, which helps them preserve learning certifications and community reputation regardless of organizational changes.

entry.title: Everything You Need to Know About the SAP Young Professionals Program
entry.content:
If you’re an ambitious graduate looking to launch your tech consulting career, the SAP Young Professionals program might be the opportunity you’ve been waiting for! This free, immersive training experience opens doors to become an SAP Associate Consultant and kick-start your career among SAP's. 

What is the SAP Young Professionals program?

It is a free, 2-3 month intensive training initiative from the SAP Digital Skills Center that aims to equip recent university graduates (with less than 3 years of graduation) with SAP knowledge, soft skills, and certifications that prepare them for SAP consulting-related position within the EMEA region. 

Graduates are trained in SAP technologies such as: SAP S/4HANA , SAP Analytics Cloud ,  Artificial Intelligence , SAP Business Technology Platform , within others ((Modules may vary by cohort or region).

Who is eligible for the program?

Applicants typically need to meet the following criteria.

  • Hold a university degree (Bachelor’s or higher). 
  • Be a recent graduate (within the past 3 years).
  • Be currently unemployed or underemployed
  • Show strong English proficiency.
  • Be citizens or legal residents of the country where the program is being offered.

Note: Specific requirements may vary depending on country and region.

What does the program include?

Over the course of 2–3 months, participants will:

  • Earn globally recognized certifications 
  • Gain access to SAP Learning Hub and be trained by SAP specialists 
  • Develop soft skills
  • Have the possibility of starting your career as Associate Consultant in SAP's ecosystem (partners + customers)

Is the program really free?

Yes. The SAP Digital Skills Center delivers this program at no cost to participants as part of SAP’s mission to close the digital skills gap and support sustainable employment. SAP invests in rising talent to help drive digital transformation across industries.

Is employment guaranteed after completing the program?

While job placement is not guaranteed, one of the key goals of YPP is to connect graduates with SAP partners and customers who are actively hiring. Many graduates secure employment within the SAP ecosystem shortly after completing the program. However, success depends on the graduate's performance, certification results, and engagement throughout the course.

How to apply?

Applications are submitted via 👉  SAP Digital Skills Center portal.

Keep an eye on the website or SAP’s social media channels for announcements about new program cohorts in your region.

Written by Valentina Guevara.

entry.title: Re: Buyoffs in SAP Digital Manufacturing: Streamlining Approvals and Enhancing Compliance
entry.content:
Hi, see some thoughts below:

  1. I see your buyoff has too many assignments and one of them could be wrong, causing the issue; I suggest you start simple, add a single assignment to material or work center, for example, and retry. Later on you can add more assignments and retest.

  2. Buyoff is triggered on Complete. In your last screenshot, I see the SFC is still active and in the top right corner a red "1" for an error is shown, but I can´t tell which error is it, so I assume you tried to complete and got an error, which might give um a hint on what is wrong.
  3. As I see 'Charge' and 'Phase' in your screenshot, I assume you are running a Process Order, and I´m afraid buyoff doesn't support Process Orders, only Production Orders.

If you still find any issues, I suggest you raise a ticket for further investigation and support.

Hope it helps! Br, Manoel

entry.title: Re: SAP Public cloud and Warehouse bin migration object
entry.content:
Hello ST24,

Can you please create ticket for this. The data migration object is build to create Warehouse bins not to update them. The migration object documentation is correct if it is saying that it cannot update existing bins. The enhanced documentation (tooltip)  is indeed misleading here. Probably because it is also reused in other objects where Bin must already exists. As the data migration object only calls warehouse APIs the error might be within the API that throws that error message.

This must be investigated and solved. Please, create a ticket here to component CA-GTF-MIG that this issue can be investigated further and solved.

Thx and BR

Frank

entry.title: Re: Multiple entries in VEKP for the same EXIDV in EWM de...
entry.content:
Yes, this is a standard behavior in decentralized EWM scenarios. When you transfer HUs from your ERP HU-managed production plant to a decentralized EWM warehouse, the HU is first posted to in-transit stock in ERP (special stock type 'O'), then replicated into EWM, which creates its own HU record with the same EXIDV. When the HU is sent back to ERP, another HU record may be created or reactivated, depending on how the return is processed. This leads to multiple VEKP entries for the same HU number; each representing a different phase or system context.

To manage this behavior and prevent HU duplication or confusion, here’s what you can do:

  • When the HU leaves ERP for EWM, make sure it’s marked as closed (status 0060) if it’s not expected to return. This prevents the HU from remaining active in ERP and avoids duplicate records when it comes back.
  • Configure EWM and ERP integration to reuse existing HU records rather than creating new ones. This may require enhancement logic or BAdIs at the inbound delivery interface to match and update the original HU instead of generating a new VEKP entry.
  • Use HUMO (ERP) and /SCWM/HUMO (EWM) to track HU status and transitions. Identify obsolete or duplicate HUs and clean them up using standard reports or manual closure.

entry.title: Re: Returning an SFC in 'Done' Status Back to Its Original Routing in SAP DM
entry.content: @IsabelTh we have set up an NC with standard RETURN_TO_ANY Nonconformance Disposition Routing assigned to it. Afterwards we log that NC on the 'Done' SFC and do the disposition.  SFCs is back on its original operation then. Pretty straight forward, seems so work since that fix from SAP. Good luck!

entry.title: Re: Work Items in Customer Projects and Line Items in Gen...
entry.content:
Hi @Alynne 

Thank you for your question and I hope the late response will still provide some valuable insights.

The “Work Item ID” you see as a column in the Display Line Items in General Ledger app F2217 can cause some confusion.

  1. Here are how work Item in Customer Projects compare to GL Line Items
  • Work Packages and Work Items are project planning entities in Customer Projects.
  • When you post actuals for example time confirmation, expense and supplier invoice, the system derives WBS element / Work Package as the controlling object for postings.
  • However, the Work Item ID in the Universal Journal is not populated from Customer Projects.
  1. Here is what the “Work Item ID” Field in GL Represents
  • The field is technically available in ACDOCA but is reserved for integration with other applications for example HR mini-master and external project systems.
  • In S/4HANA Public Cloud, Customer Projects does not transfer Work Item ID into ACDOCA. Only the Work Package and Project ID are passed.
  1. Here are reasons why you don’t see Work Item ID in GL
  • Please note, by design, GL line items will not show Work Item ID from Customer Projects.
  • Tracking at the Work Item level is supported for planning and project execution reports within Customer Projects, but not in financial postings.
  • Financial integration is at the Project à Work Package granularity, not down to Work Item.
  1. Here are possible options if you need Work Item-Level Tracking in Finance
  • Use Customer Projects reporting apps such as Analyse Project Costs F3473 or Project Profitability apps, where Work Item information is available.
  • If you require Work Item information in accounting, you will need to use extensibility for example custom field and logic to transfer Work Item into ACDOCA. At present, SAP does not deliver this mapping as standard.

These references will provide more details:

Customer Projects in S/4HANA Cloud

Universal Journal Line Items (ACDOCA)

SAP Note 3288817 – Work Item Field Not Populated in GL Line Items (explains the limitation).

 

I hope this provides the necessary guidance. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: 🟣 Create a Case in Service Cloud V2 by Uploading Images Using AI Core, Build Apps
entry.content:
In this demo, we showcase an intelligent self-service portal built using SAP Build Apps, and integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. What's the magic?
 
Users can raise service requests by simply uploading an image through the portal, triggering a case creation in Service Cloud V2. Leveraging SAP AI Core, the uploaded image is analyzed to detect key objects or issues, and the service ticket description is auto-updated with intelligent insights. AI sentiment analysis is applied to the description, helping to prioritize and categorize cases more effectively. This end-to-end workflow shows how low-code tools and AI-driven automation can transform customer service experiences by reducing manual effort, improving accuracy, and accelerating resolution time.

entry.title: GRC BRM: Update of OVM Landscape
entry.content:
Hi Community,

We created OVMs for a specific landscape and used these OVMs to derive roles. Due to the migration of systems to Google Cloud, the customer now requires us to create a new landscape and import all roles from the original landscape to the new one. The original landscape will then be archived and no longer used.
However, it is not possible to change the landscape in OVM. After importing into the new landscape, the derived roles would contain OVM that belong to a different landscape. Is there any way to change the landscape in OVM?

Thank you in advance for your answer.

entry.title: Re: Functional Specification
entry.content:
It cannot be explained just like that how to write FS and over by years, you will gain knwoledge on that but I can share some tips how your FS should be:

  • Be precise: Avoid vague terms like “etc.” or “as needed”
  • Use SAP terminology: Refer to transactions (e.g., ME2N), tables (e.g., EBAN), and fields clearly
  • Think like a user: Describe how the report or enhancement will be used in daily operations
  • Collaborate with ABAPers: Ask what technical details they need — it improves clarity
  • Include screenshots or mockups: Visuals help developers understand layout expectations


With the above, let me give you one example scenario for you to prepare FS

So the Business requirement is to create a custom report to list all open Purchase Requisitions by plant and material group, with selection fields for purchasing group and date range.

For the above requirement, start the FS with the above tips as much as possible. In fact, I would recommend you sit with your ABAP colleague and take the inputs across the table. Because, it is always effective with one to one personal discussion.  Then only, you will understand why certain tables can be considered and why not others while brainstorming. This approach will be more effective than asking in forum.

entry.title: Re: Warehouse number created wrongly with 3 digits, is th...
entry.content:
Hi,
As per standard practice, once the warehouse (WH) has been created and saved, please ensure that no additional configurations have been made and no documents have been posted against it. If that's the case, proceed to delete the existing warehouse and create a new one.

Also, you may proceed with the 3-Digit code.

Please note: Warehouse Management (WM) supports 3-digit warehouse numbers, whereas Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) allows 4-digit codes.

Best Regards,

Aman

entry.title: Thumbs Up for the New “Kudos Received” Progression Badges!
entry.content:
The members have spoken. The relaunch of our progression badge sets is a hit!

We started last week by rolling out four new badges that reward members for providing solutions to questions. Response to my announcement in What’s New has been extremely positive.  “Bringing Back Badges to Reward Q&A Experts!” has thousands of views and dozens of kudos. Good thing for me, because the next progression set celebrates members for the number of kudos they received – so all those recent kudos sure will come in handy toward my progress!

Whether you call them a thumbs-up (as they appear in the site design), a like (as they were known in the previous SAP Community platform), or a kudo (as they’re called in our current platform), you know that your content has found an audience when members take the time to click that lovely little icon to show their appreciation for your contribution. And we know you’re the kind of member who deserves special gamification rewards!

As with the “solutions” badge set, this new set will have five badges in total, although the first badge has been available since the launch of our latest community platform last year. We’ve added four more badges to this set, and you progress based on the number of kudos received. Per the image below, the second badge requires 50 kudos, the third requires 100, the fourth requires 200, and the fifth requires 500.

We’ll launch these badges at some point tomorrow, Thursday, August 28, one at a time over a period of a few hours. Depending on how many kudos you’ve received, don’t be surprised if you get multiple notifications as the badge assignment occurs during this period. (If you’re still waiting by Friday, August 29, try logging out and in again. Any new badges should show up then.)

Once again, we’ll award these badges retroactively. Any numbers migrated from the previous platform to this one count toward your progress, and kudos for any content type (e.g., blog post, comment) count as well. So if you’ve been contributing popular content for years, you may have done enough to earn all five badges.

Wondering if you’re already part of the “500+ kudos received” club? You can check for yourself in your “My content” area. In my last post, I provided instructions about how to find your content, but here’s a reminder for your convenience.

First, make sure you’ve logged in. Click on the person icon in the upper right of any community page. Select “My content” from the dropdown.

“Kudos received” appears in the gray box at the very top. To help illustrate, I’m once again relying on the anonymous member who appeared in last week’s post, by sharing a screenshot from his “My content” page. (He didn’t complain then, so I hope he doesn’t mind now. Or maybe he just hasn’t noticed yet.)

Looks like this community veteran has received thousands of kudos over the years – more than enough to rack up all four badges tomorrow.

How about you? If you’re expecting all four of the new badges tomorrow, then kudos to you! (Pun intended.) Whether you receive one, five, or any number in between, we appreciate your involvement in SAP Community. More importantly, our members appreciate your activity – evidenced by all their kudos for you!

If you don’t get a badge (or get one or some but want them all), you’ll have plenty of opportunity in future to complete the set. All you need to do is continue to contribute quality content to SAP Community. If members like what you’re sharing, you can eventually accrue enough kudos to work your way through this new progression set.

Not the kind of member who likes to publish content? That’s OK. We have more progression badge sets coming in the weeks ahead, and not all of them depend on posting to SAP Community. There are lots of things members can do to create a positive community, and we’ll be awarding badges for those, too.

Look for updates here in the What’s New section to learn how you can receive gamification rewards as we introduce new progression sets. One thing is certain: The more you do in SAP Community, the more badges you can earn. My advice if you’re a badge hunter? Stay active. Stay engaged. In short, stay an important part of SAP Community. We look forward to recognizing all members who make our community a better place!

entry.title: I am looking for way to run MD51 project planning in the background.
entry.content:
There are no run in background function in this tcode. MDBT only support plant level planning.

There are requirement to run WBS with MRP control parameters different from plant.

SAP ERP #MD51 #Project_planning #background_job #production_lot

entry.title: 🟣 Generate Process Artifacts by Importing BPMN Models from any Process Design Tool
entry.content: Process modeling and documentation often happens in external tools, such as SAP Signavio, using BPMN, and subsequently implementing executable process automations can be time-consuming and difficult. SAP Business Process Automation now lets you import BMPN models that were exported from any external process-modeling tool.

entry.title: 🟣 Document Translation with SAP Build Apps and Translation Hub
entry.content: In this interactive, discover the key capabilities of SAP Translation Hub and how to make use of them through SAP Build Apps. Then you'll see how to build a no-code translation solution using SAP Build Apps and SAP Translation Hub, letting the user perform both language translation and document translation -- all without writing a single line of code.

entry.title: Re: How can I create a button that fully replicates Edit...
entry.content: Thanks for the bookmark tip! Is there any way to apply a (global) bookmark silently, i.e., without the visible page refresh/flicker? When I apply a bookmark from a button, the whole app appears to re-render—as if the user had pressed F5. Is there an API flag/parameter to suppress the UI refresh or apply the bookmark in a “silent” mode? If not, what’s the recommended workaround to make this seamless (e.g., per-page bookmarks, freezing the UI, etc.)?

entry.title: 🟣 Taking guided experiences with SAP Build to the next level
entry.content: SAP Build Guided Experience” powered by SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Build Process Automation is an intuitive user interface to guide you through a sequence of steps or actions enabling business users to simplify complex business processes into self-service journeys. Guided Experiences help navigate through complex business processes such as parental leave, benefits enrollment, employee relocation, new hire or supplier onboarding, training and enablement, or browsing and & purchasing electronic equipment. Users can model intuitive stages and stages which can by further enriched with content, documents, forms, UI cards and more. Stay tuned to deep-dive into its capabilities!

entry.title: 🟣 From Clicks to Code: Automate SAP BTP Setup with Terraform
entry.content: This session introduces developers to the world of Infrastructure as code, as we explore Terraform and the Terraform Providers for SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry. We’ll start with the fundamentals of Terraform and explore how it enables consistent, repeatable, and version-controlled resource management. This will be done through a simple and practical hands on scenario where we will configure SAP BTP and deploy an app on Cloud Foundry -- all through code. This session will equip the participants with the ability to streamline their deployment workflows.

Hiding the Create button can be achieved by commenting out use create; in the behavior definition for the interface view and keep create ( features: global ); in the consumption view.

create ( features : global ); "Keep create in behaviour definition for consumption view

entry.title: MDG upgrade from 1909 to MDG 2023 - UIBB Customizations overwritten
entry.content:
Hello All, 

After upgrading our MDG system from 1909 to 2023, we have observed the following issues:
• All UIBBs and fields are now visible, including those that were previously hidden.
• Our customized fields and configurations seem to be overwritten by the standard SAP delivery.
• The customizations still exist in the system, but instead of showing our configured fields, the standard fields are now appearing.

Question:
Post-upgrade, will all customizations made on top of standard configurations (UIBBs, hidden fields, etc.) be overwritten in 2023?
What is the recommended approach to preserve or reapply these customizations after an upgrade?

Thanks in advance for your insights.

entry.title: Re: Evaluating Risks of Non-VPN Access to SAP BTP Cockpit
entry.content:
Hi

Instead of use S-Users yo should integrate with your IDP. It has many benefits: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/bringing-your-corporate-identity-provider-for-platform-users

in this scenario the Platform Users will access BTP Cockpit via IAS and then you usually configure IAS to your corporate IDP. In this scenario you can apply some rules in IAS itself (if you're not using custom IDP) or if you're using Entra or simmilar you have the ability to block the access to the app by a wide set of criterias (device, location, risk, etc).

You should keep the access with S-User to your cockpit only to a limited number of users or maybe only to a Emergency user. You should keep at least one for emergency scenarios.

entry.title: ADT: “Review Proposal” dialog keeps popping up whenever Suggest keywords is enabled
entry.content:
Hi,

After updating my ADT plugins in Eclipse, I’m seeing a new behavior with code completion.
If I enable Preferences → ABAP Development → Editors → Source Code Editors → Code Completion → Suggest keywords, a modal “Completion → Review Proposal” window pops up while I’m typing

E.g., as soon as I type sel it shows a proposal for select). This happens constantly and interrupts typing.

 

I would like to keep Suggest keywords (very helpful) but without that modal dialog.

Is anyone else facing this issue?

Thanks.

entry.title: Re: How to do budgets for purchase in sap s4 hana public...
entry.content:
Budgeting for Purchase (Procurement)

To manage procurement budgets, you’ll typically use cost center budgeting and availability control:

1) Define Budget-Relevant G/L Accounts

In the G/L master data, flag accounts as budget-relevant under the Public Sector Management Data tab.

2) Create Budget Documents

Use the Manage Budget Documents Fiori app to enter budgets manually. You can also upload budgets via Excel or integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud.

3) Assign Budgets to Cost Centers

Budgets are linked to cost centers, funds, or functional areas depending on your setup.

4) Enable Availability Control

This ensures that purchase requisitions and orders are checked against available budget. Only expense-type entries are included in availability control.


Budgeting for Sales (Revenue Planning)

Sales budgeting is more about forecasting and planning than hard availability control:

1) Use SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

SAC is the recommended tool for sales planning, revenue projections, and profitability analysis. You can model revenue by product, region, customer group, etc.

2) Integrate with S/4HANA Cloud

Budget data from SAC can be pushed into S/4HANA Cloud using OData services. Revenue budgets can be used for Revenue Increasing Budget (RIB) functionality.

3) Monitor via ACDOCP Table

All budget entries (expense and revenue) are stored in ACDOCP, the central planning table.

entry.title: Configuring SAP Cloud Integration for an IBP to S/4HANA (on prem / private cloud) integration
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

Following a first entry blog on introducing SAP Cloud Integration from Integration Services as the new time series ETL for IBP integration, here is a second sharing focusing this time on configuring the Integration Suite to lay the groundwork for integration flow creation.

---------------

 Again, to all customers/partners out there working with CI-DS : there is currently no plan to sunset CI-DS, it will continue to be supported by SAP in the future.

---------------

Before proceeding, please make sure you meet the below prerequisites.

Prerequisites

  • All steps from my first technical setup blog entry.  
  • The SAP Cloud connector for S/4HANA (on premise or private cloud) has been installed and configured to connect your SAP IBP and SAP S/4HANA instances.
      • More info on installation steps  : SAP BTP Connectivity – Installation.
      • More info on the configuration, including how to setup the password for the Administrator user : SAP BTP Connectivity – Initial Configuration.
  • Users have been created via the BTP cockpit with the relevant roles depending on what tasks they need to perform. The three typical roles for CI are the following: PI_Administrator, PI_Integration_Developer and PI_Business_Expert. Check the Personas for CI information to understand what each covers in order to assign the most relevant ones.
    • To support actions from this blog entry you need the PI_Integration_Developer role.
  • The SAP S/4HANA, Supply Chain Integration Add-On for SAP Integrated Business Planning is configured in S/4HANA for integration purposes.

 

Defining the Destinations

Before you can begin designing iflows, you must start by defining your source and target systems as you would typically do for CI-DS (Datastore section).

Configure IBP as a Destination

For the Integration Suite, you need to perform this action on the BTP subaccount level of your BTP cockpit.

  • First find the path from your BTP cockpit: Account Explorer > Global Account > Subaccounts tab, and select your subaccount as seen in the previous blog entry on how to setup the technical landscape in BTP.
  • Navigate to the Account Overview screen and select Connectivity > Destinations from the left side panel.
  • Start by creating a destination to model your IBP tenant by selecting the “Create” button

  • Choose “From scratch”
  • Then populate at least the following fields:
    • Name, I suggest identifying your IBP destination with its tenant code in the XXX format as shown below,
    • Type : RFC,
    • Description, optional details on the destination can be added,
    • Proxy Type : Internet,
    • Alias User, represents the Communication User created previously in IBP, in our example USR_SAP_COM_931,
    • Password, the password set for the Communication User in IBP,
    • WebSocket RFC Server Host, your IBP tenant url in the format “myXXXXXX-api.scmibp1.ondemand.com”,
    • WebSocket RFC Server Port: 443,
    • Client: 100.

  • Click on Create.

To check the connection is setup correctly, you can use the “Check Connection” button after saving, located on the top right-hand corner of the Destination configuration screen

You should get the following success message:

Now you need to configure your S/4HANA system as a destination to start building iflows.

 

Configure S/4HANA as a Destination

From the Destinations list,

  • Choose once again “Create” and “From scratch” as done to configure the IBP destination.
  • Then populate at least the following fields:
    • Name, I suggest identifying your IBP S/4HANA destination with its tenant and client codes as shown below,
    • Type : RFC,
    • Description, optional details on the destination can be added,
    • Proxy Type : On Premise,
    • User, represents the technical user that must first exist in your S/4HANA system with necessary authorizations assigned (you can use template role SAP_IBPECC_CI_RFC_1.0),
    • Password, the password set for the above technical user in S/4HANA,
    • Location ID, if you set a location ID during the Cloud Connector configuration set the same name here (which you can check in the left side panel: Connectivity > Cloud Connectors),

Example:

 

 In the Target System Configuration section, set the following:

  • Virtual Application Server Host, the virtual host name used during the Cloud Connector configuration (which you can check in the left side panel: Connectivity > Cloud Connectors),

  • System Number, your S/4HANA system number used for this integration,
  • Client, your S/4HANA client used for this integration.

Example:

  • Click on Create.

To check the connection is setup correctly, you can use the “Check Connection” button after saving, located on the top right-hand corner of the Destination configuration screen.

You should get the below message:

 

 

Lay the groundwork for building Iflows

Now that the technical setup is completed and connections have been configured and tested, you can proceed with building integration content.

The first thing you’ll need to do is leverage the pre-built integration content delivered by SAP.

Access your Integration Suite tenant, you can do so either with the direct URL or via your BTP cockpit, select your subaccount and from the left side panel Instances and Subscriptions. From there, see below screenshot, find your Integration Suite subscription and find the Go to Application option from the menu.

In the next entries we will focus essentially on these three sections of the Integration Suite:

  • Discover
    This section offers preconfigured packages delivered by SAP that can help accelerate your integration work. A package regroups integration flows (hereafter referred to as iflows), documentation, value mappings and other so-called artifacts to help you cover a specific integration scenario.
  • Design
    The Design section is where you create your iflows. To begin you can copy packages from the Discover section or create a package of your own from scratch.
  • Monitor
    Here you can monitor your executed iflows once deployed.

Let’s now introduce the preconfigured packages that will be relevant for the IBP – S/4HANA (private cloud / on-premise) integration, specifically based on the use of the SAP S/4HANA, Supply Chain Integration Add-On for SAP Integrated Business Planning.

In the Discover section look for the following three packages:

  • SAP IBP - Reusable Integration Flows
  • SAP IBP Add-On - Reusable Integration Flows
  • SAP IBP - Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP

 

 You’ll need to copy each of them into the Design section. To do this, access the first one by clicking on the entry itself which brings you to the content of the package and select “Copy”.

Do this for the two other packages and now access the Design section to confirm all three have been correctly copied in your working environment.

 

Now any iflows that you will build to support your integration project will necessarily be composed of so-called reusable iflows which are part of these preconfigured packages delivered by SAP.

A reusable iflow is a prebuilt sequence allowing to perform a particular action in a source or target system. Let’s just say it encapsulates SAP Best Practices in terms of design (necessary checks, logging exception messages, opening and closing a connection to the system, etc.) with a single role that could be reading data from S/4HANA, fetching and posting data in IBP, reading data in IBP or initializing the iflow.

The iflows that you will create, we call them business iflows, will use a series of these reusable iflows depending on what your need done. To be able to execute an iflow, it first needs to be deployed and because your business iflow will incorporate sub iflows including reusable iflows, it is essential all of these are deployed first so let’s tackle this action.

To deploy you reusable iflows, you need to do the following for all artifacts of both packages SAP IBP - Reusable Integration Flows and SAP IBP Add-On - Reusable Integration Flows:

  • Access the package
  • Navigate to the Artifact tab
  • For each iflow in this section, select the menu (three dots on the right) and click on Deploy

 

  • Click on Yes in the confirmation dialog.

At some point you should get the following notification on the bottom of the screen:

You can also check this in the Monitor section from the left side panel, choose Manage Integration Content

Check the status on the iflow previously deployed.

Again: do this for ALL iflows within the Artifacts tab of BOTH of the reusable iflows packages.

 

In the next blog entry, we shall create a first customer iflow based on reusable iflows to call data from S/4HANA via its integration addon (calling an extractor directly as CI-DS would) and see how we can influence the call via mappings and filters.

Stay Tuned!

 

Sources 

  • Overview of SAP Integration Suite and SAP Cloud Integration
  • Connection setup guide https://me.sap.com/notes/3628813

Velu

SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: Table maintenance alternatives in S/4HANA on premise
entry.content:
Hi,

We are working on defining best practice guidelines for creating maintenance objects in S/4HANA on promise. Depending on complexity, there seem to be a few options:

  • Using a simple Table Maintenance View from GUI with a Fiori Launchpad tile .
  • Using the Fiori app “Custom Business Objects”, which generates a BOPF object in the background.
  • Creating a ‘Maintenance Object’ from Eclipse, which generates a RAP-based solution.

Since SAP provides the Custom Business Objects app, it could be a valid option, but RAP is the strategic direction.

I would appreciate recommendations or best practices on which approach to choose for both small/simple and more complex maintenance/configuration tables. No step-by-step instructions are needed; I am primarily looking for guidance on the preferred approach.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Create and update action in custom table while implem...
entry.content:
Hi @Shadab_Hussain67 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Cloud BAdIs run under strict transactional contracts. The error you are seeing means that the BAdI you are implementing is defined as FUNCTIONAL. Such BAdIs are read-only and are not allowed to perform database changes such as INSERT, UPDATE, MODIFY and DELETE.

  1. Here is why you Cannot update a Table here
  • badi_mmim_check_matdocitem is a check BAdI.
  • It is intended only for validations during material document item processing.
  • Database updates are not permitted because they would interfere with the posting transaction.
  1. Here is how to handle your Use Case

If you need to persist additional data like yield quantity and validate against it later, you have the two following options:

  1. Make use of a Persistency BAdI / SAVE phase
    • Move your database INSERT/UPDATE logic into a BAdI that supports persistence
    • An example is a post-document processing BAdI such as badi_mmim_post_matdocitem
  2. Decouple Validation from Persistency
    • In the check BAdI, only perform the validation logic. Compare current quantities with what is already stored.
    • For saving additional data, create a separate custom business object using Developer Extensibility or Key User Custom Business Object, and update it in a permitted lifecycle BAdI.
  3. Here is an alternative Event Handling
    • In some scenarios, you can trigger persistence through an RAP Business Event or custom handler attached to a business object extension, rather than directly modifying a table inside a functional BAdI.

Here are references that will provides more details.

BAdIs and Transactional Contracts in S/4HANA Cloud

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: DAP DM - EWM Goods Receipt failed - how to post a pac...
entry.content: Hi Daniel, /v1/inventory/ewmGoodsReceipts functionality is the same as in 'Goods Receipt' POD Plugin in 'Order POD' execution flow, mostly used for Process Industry/Order execution. For a Discrete Industry/Order execution flow, you might want to evaluate using Packing APIs, to perform the same steps you perform in Work Center POD using Packing POD Plugin. See https://api.sap.com/api/sapdme_packingunit/resource/Packing. If my answer was helpful, please consider accepting it as solution. Hope it helps! Br, Manoel

entry.title: Business Intelligence, Analytics & Predictive Analytics for Consultants- Without the Tech Jargon
entry.content:
Breaking into the world of Consulting has never been more exciting. Whether you’re aiming to specialize in business or cloud technologies, one skillset cuts across all: understanding Business Intelligence and Analytics.  

Why? Because you’ll be advising clients on how to make decisions, and knowing the basics of BI and Analytics enables you to connect technical solutions with real business value, and this is something you can’t afford to ignore if you want to stand out as a tech consultant in the SAP ecosystem. Read through -> at the end, we’ll share the key resource that connects directly to your next step as a consultant.

What is Business Intelligence (BI), in simple terms? 

Business Intelligence (BI) is all about using tools and procedures to analyze and transform data into meaningful information. The goal? Helping companies make better and faster decisions. Whether it's a sales team spotting trends or the finance department looking for cost-saving opportunities, BI turns data into actionable insights for decision makers.  

Let’s break it down with a simple example 👇:   

Imagine you are advising a small grocery store with a cash register. After each sale, they print the receipt and pile them up on your desk.  Each receipt provides details like: 

  • What product was sold 
  • The price 
  • The brand 
  • The time of the sale 
  • Which store location 

Now, if all those receipts just sit there in a messy pile without having structure or meaning, it’s nothing more than clutter!  This is where BI, analytics, and Predictive Analytics come in. By using BI, you can turn the cash register’s data into simple visuals that show: 

  • Your top-selling products 
  • Peak sales hours 
  • Brands that bring the most profit 
  • Stores that are performing best 

Wow! Now your client can make decisions with information that makes sense and leads to action. Therefore, if you see that soda sales double on Saturdays, you can advise them to stock more and keep folks happy. 

And what are the 5 stages of Business Intelligence? 

  1. Collecting data from your store, customers, etc. 
  2. Storing it in one place (like a database) 
  3. Cleaning and modeling it (Analytics again) 
  4. Visualizing and examining it (BI) 
  5. Taking action with that insight 

 What is the difference between Analytics and BI? 

Analytics is the behind-the-scenes work: gathering all those receipts, cleaning mistakes (like wrong prices or product names), calculating new stuff (like profit or days payable outstanding), and structuring the data so it makes sense. However, Business Intelligence comes after: it’s visualizing the cleaned data in charts or dashboards, reports, and charts that anyone can understand. 

So, what about Predictive Analytics? 

If BI helps you understand the past and present, Predictive Analytics helps you plan, using past records to predict the future. For example, if December always brings a 40% uptick in chocolate sales, you can predict it’ll happen again and advise your client to prepare for this seasonal demand.  

Types of Predictive Analytics You’ll Encounter 

Depending on what you want to peek into the future, you’ll need to use different approaches:  

  • Regression: Predicting numbers (e.g., next month’s sales) 
  • Classification: Predicting categories (e.g., “Will this customer churn?”) 
  • Segmentation: Grouping customers with similar behavior 
  • Time-series: Forecasting trends over time (e.g., seasonal trend sales) 

Now, imagine scaling that grocery store to a multinational retailer client with millions of daily transactions. At that scale, you need robust tools to handle massive amounts of data, and that’s where SAP comes in. 

  • In SAP Datasphere, you can gather, integrate, and model your cash register data (and other sources) for data analytics. 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) turns those models into dashboards, planning tools, and interactive visual stories (known as Intelligent Applications in SAP). This is where BI is done.   
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), a cloud-native SaaS solution, combines Datasphere, SAC, SAP Business Warehouse (BW), and adds SAP Databricks for advanced AI and machine learning capabilities, allowing you to perform predictive analytics.  

Knowing how these pieces fit together will enable you to communicate confidently with both technical teams and business stakeholders, making you a more valuable consultant. 

🔵Ready to kickstart your career as a Consultant in SAP’s Ecosystem? 

Explore the SAP Digital Skills Center and discover our programs in your region (Only applicable for fresh graduates, unemployed, or underemployed in the EMEA region).  

Co-authored by @ByronCarvajalP and  @lauravalentina_guevaradavila

entry.title: SAP Meetup Cyprus – Networking & Insights
entry.content:
After many requests, our SAP Stammtisch in Cyprus is back! 🎉
We had such great energy last time, so we’re continuing the tradition – even bigger and better.

This time the focus will be on Logistics with S/4HANA. We’ll share useful tips & tricks, discuss real experiences, and of course have plenty of space for open exchange and networking.

It’s not just about SAP – it’s about meeting great people, sharing ideas, and enjoying the evening together.

I’m really looking forward to seeing you all again – and to welcoming new faces who want to join our growing SAP community here in Cyprus. 🌍

Let’s make it another inspiring evening together!

entry.title: Information and Lifecycle Management; Exception Process for Business Document Retention Periods
entry.content:
We have recently configured Information Lifecycle Management in our environment and maintained Retention Rules for the different document types.

In some cases it will be necessary to retain documents beyond the Retention Period. 

Is there a process which we can use to flag such documents?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Information and Lifecycle Management; Exception Proce...
entry.content:
Yes, you can overrule the residence and retention end dates using the Overrule Retention Settings option which you can find in the Lifecycle Items view.

The button should be visible above the table in the Lifecycle Items view; where you would expect to find the Actions button in other views.

More details can be found in the Help Documentation linked below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_BYDESIGN/2754875d2d2a403f95e58a41a9c7d6de/75c8834ca357487db84610783f99f670.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

entry.title: Algorithm 015 only checks 13 chars (CHECT). How to clear on full reference?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We clear outgoing vendor payments via bank transfer. The bank provides a transaction reference (16–18 characters). Users store the same value in the FI document Assignment (BSEG-ZUONR). On EBS import (MT940) I want clearing to happen based on that full reference.

Configuration:

  • S4 HANA 2021

  • Interpretation algorithm 015 – Clearing: transaction selection using assignment.

  • Posting rules and external transactions are assigned as usual.

Problem:
During interpretation/clearing the system seems to evaluate only 13 characters of the reference, so the match fails. In the tables I see FEBEP-CHECT (length 13) being populated; FEBA log shows only the first 13 digits used for selection.

Questions:

  1. Is Algorithm 015 hard-coded to use CHECT (13) instead of ZUONR (18), hence the truncation?

  2. What is the standard way to clear on a full 16–18 char reference from MT940?

    • Can 015 be made to read the ZUONR value filled via Search String?

    • Or is there another interpretation algorithm that checks ZUONR (18) rather than CHECT?

  3. If customizing cannot achieve this, which enhancement is recommended by SAP?

    • BAdI FIEB_CHANGE_BS_DATA (pre-interpretation) to normalize reference and/or move it, then clear?

    • custom interpretation algorithm to avoid the 13-char limit?

Thanks in advance for guidance on the correct standard approach.

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud TM: prevent freight unit creation for PO...
entry.content: Hi Woflgang, in SAP Cloud Public edition, you can use App Manage Condition to prevent auto creation of Freight Unit

entry.title: Re: I am looking for way to run MD51 project planning in...
entry.content:
One workaround is use MRP Groups for Granular Control. This is the most SAP-standard way to achieve what you're asking.

  • Create MRP Groups in customizing SPRO → Production → MRP → Planning → Define MRP Groups
  • Assign different MRP control parameters (planning mode, creation indicators, etc.) to each group
  • In the material master, assign the appropriate MRP Group to materials linked to specific WBS elements

This allows you to run MD51 and have materials behave differently based on their assigned MRP Group — even within the same plant.

entry.title: कुकू एफएम से पैसा वापस कैसे करें?
entry.content: इसके लिए आपको ™Kuku Fm™ टोल फ्री नंबर 00,6266✓513—796 पर कॉल करना होगा। कुकू एफएम से पैसे कैसे वापस पाएं. इसके लिए आपको ™Kuku Fm™ टोल फ्री नंबर (06266—513✓796/*+} पर कॉल करना होगा।

entry.title: Re: Please let me know CDS views for extractor 0CO_OM_NWA...
entry.content:
Hi @vijay_k1 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the classic BW extractors like 0CO_OM_NWA_2 for Internal Orders and 0CO_OM_WBS_6 for WBS Elements are replaced by released CDS views.

  1. Replacement for 0CO_OM_NWA_2

Use the released CDS view:

  • I_ActualCostLineItem Actual Cost Line Item – Universal Journal
  • Depending on your reporting requirements, you may also use:
    • I_ActualCostLineItemCube, which is the Analytical cube view
    • C_ActualCostLineItemQ2202, which Consumption view for analytics
  1. Replacement for 0CO_OM_WBS_6

Use the released CDS views for project-related postings:

  • I_ActualCostLineItemWBS, which is Actual Cost Line Item by WBS Element
  • Also relevant for analytics:
    • I_ProjectWBSActualCostItemCube
    • C_ProjectWBSActualCostItem, which is the consumption view
  1. Where to Find Them

You can explore these CDS views in your system via:

  • App View Browser, the Fiori ID: F2170
  • App Custom CDS View, Fiori ID: F1866 if you want to build on top of them.

Here are some references that guides you further:

 CDS Views for Universal Journal in S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Community solution: Replacing CO Extractors with CDS Views

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
